item.title: Kojima Has Explained Why Solid Snake Was a ‘Silent Tough Guy’
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/kojima-explain-why-solid-snake-silent-tough-guy/

Hideo Kojima created and released Metal Gear in 1987, introducing Solid Snake to the world. He would go on to become one of the most widely recognised characters in gaming, but his first outing rendered him a silent, stalwart figure incapable of uttering a single word.

Kojima has gone on record explaining why Solid Snake was silent, breaking down his earliest experiences with voice actors and reflecting on past technologies.

‘Games Still Couldn’t Speak’

In a recent interview with An An (thanks to Automaton), Hideo Kojima explained at length why Solid Snake was a silent protagonist in the first Metal Gear game that debuted in the late eighties:

In 1986, when I entered the game industry, games still couldn’t speak. The characters didn’t have voices. There wasn’t even a kanji font, and the characters were just displayed one by one. Solid Snake, the protagonist of my debut game, Metal Gear (1987), was born as a silent tough guy because of this.

It didn’t take long for things to change, though. The legendary developer revealed that just one year after Metal Gear was released, a technological leap forward occurred when NEC released the CD-ROM2, a console with a disc drive. This was an evolution that accommodated Kojima’s desires:

Because the media was CD, it was possible to use voice dialogue, which had not been possible until then. I was one of the first to step forward and remake it.

It was my first time doing voice recordings. I did the casting myself, but since I was a complete outsider, I left the management to an agency. I took the first bullet train from Kobe and arrived at the studio in Tokyo. The gorgeous voice actors were already standing by in front of the microphone.

There was no time to greet or even have a meeting. It was an outrageous schedule, with everything recorded in almost half a day. There was no way I could build relationships. The regret and regret of this first experience would greatly change my subsequent voice recordings. 

(Text translated from Japanese by AI)

From there, history started being made, and Kojima went on to explain how his various teams tried to innovate in the voice recording department whenever possible. Today, Kojima’s games feature Hollywood celebrities and deeply cinematic scripts and performances, so it’s fair to say he was successful in that mission.

item.title: Call of Duty Warzone April 7 Patch Notes—Buy Stations Receive Major Update & Attachments Suddenly Removed
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/call-of-duty-warzone-april-7-patch-notes-buy-stations-receive-major-update-attachments-suddenly-removed/

Raven Software was forced to step in on April 7 with a new Warzone update in Verdansk after two weapon attachments became overpowered and the number of Buy Stations in trios was incorrect.

It’s not unusual for Warzone updates to accidentally introduce new issues, but Season 3 avoided glaring setbacks. Despite some complaints about the HDR being too powerful and not having enough armor plates on the map, players have enjoyed having iconic weapons like the Kilo 141 back in the game.

In addition, Season 3’s weapon-balancing changes created a healthy variety of meta weapon options for short or long-range engagements. In saying that, two attachments disrupted that harmony.

Warzone April 7 Patch Notes Explained

Snakeshot Ammunition and Thermal 6x Scope Removed

.500 Snakeshot Ammunition is an attachment for the Basilisk pistol that transforms the weapon into a shotgun in close-range engagements. Over the years, there have been several instances of the attachment becoming too powerful in Warzone, and it happened again in Season 3.

With the ammunition type equipped with the Akimbo attachment, the pistols consistently two-shot killed enemies up close, much faster than every other short-range meta weapon.

This update temporarily restricts the attachment. Meanwhile, the Thermal 6x Scope has also been temporarily removed because the scope didn’t have any glint. This was a massive issue because scope glint helps warn players that an enemy is looking at them.

Buy Station Change

Raven Software reduced the amount of Buy Stations to Trios to better reflect the larger squad sizes. Usually, the map scales the number of available Buy Stations based on the squad size of a lobby because larger teams don’t need as many Buy Stations.

All Warzone April 7 Update Patch Notes

Activision posted the complete patch notes for Warzone’s April 7 update.

Global

  • Recently Disabled Items
    • Snakeshot Ammunition
    • Thermal 6x Scope

Battle Royale

  • Buy Stations
    • We’ve adjusted the number of static buy stations that spawn in Battle Royale Trios to match other squad sizes.

Resurgence, Plunder

  • Recently Enabled Items
    • Bunker Buster

The Warzone devs also assured players that a fix is coming to address the issue that impacts the Hybrid and Slide Only settings and announced that the Endo Titanium Core skin for the T-800 Operator skin will be nerfed to improve visibility.
